title: Verb Tenses Quiz (50 Questions) | TypoGrammar
description: Test your English verb tenses with this free 50-question quiz. Includes answers and explanations for IELTS, TOEFL, and ESL learners.

questions.sentence: She ___ to work every day.
questions.explanation: We use the present simple for routines and habits. With 'she', the verb takes -s.

questions.sentence: Right now, they ___ dinner together.
questions.explanation: Present continuous (am/is/are + -ing) is used for actions happening right now.

questions.sentence: Last week, I ___ my grandmother in the hospital.
questions.explanation: Past simple is used for completed actions at a specific time in the past (last week).

questions.sentence: Don't worry, I ___ you with your homework later.
questions.explanation: We use 'will' for spontaneous decisions and promises made at the moment of speaking.

questions.sentence: I ___ never ___ to Japan before.
questions.explanation: Present perfect (have/has + past participle) is used for life experiences without mentioning when.

questions.sentence: Water ___ at 100 degrees Celsius.
questions.explanation: Present simple is used for facts and general truths. With singular subjects, the verb takes -s.

questions.sentence: At 8 PM yesterday, we ___ TV.
questions.explanation: Past continuous (was/were + -ing) describes an action in progress at a specific time in the past.

questions.sentence: Look at those dark clouds! It ___ rain soon.
questions.explanation: We use 'going to' for predictions based on present evidence (the dark clouds).

questions.sentence: She ___ her keys and can't open the door.
questions.explanation: Present perfect shows a past action with a present result (she still can't open the door).

questions.sentence: My brother ___ in a hospital as a nurse.
questions.explanation: Present simple describes permanent situations and regular jobs. With 'he/she', add -s.

questions.sentence: They ___ the movie last night.
questions.explanation: Past simple is used for completed actions with a specific past time marker (last night).

questions.sentence: Be quiet! The baby ___.
questions.explanation: Present continuous describes an action happening at the moment of speaking.

questions.sentence: I think the team ___ the championship this year.
questions.explanation: We use 'will' for predictions or opinions about the future (I think...).

questions.sentence: We ___ here since 2015.
questions.explanation: Present perfect with 'since' describes an action that started in the past and continues now.

questions.sentence: While I ___ to school, I saw an accident.
questions.explanation: Past continuous is used for a background action interrupted by another action (saw).

questions.sentence: The sun ___ in the east.
questions.explanation: Present simple is used for permanent facts and natural phenomena. Singular subject takes -s.

questions.sentence: We ___ visit our grandparents next weekend.
questions.explanation: We use 'going to' for planned future actions or intentions already decided.

questions.sentence: Have you ___ finished your homework?
questions.explanation: 'Already' is used in present perfect questions to ask if something has happened sooner than expected.

questions.sentence: She ___ a beautiful song at the concert yesterday.
questions.explanation: Past simple is used for completed past actions with a time marker (yesterday).

questions.sentence: My parents ___ their vacation to Spain this summer.
questions.explanation: Present continuous can describe temporary actions happening around now or ongoing plans.

questions.sentence: I ___ three emails to the company, but they haven't replied yet.
questions.explanation: Present perfect connects past actions to the present situation (still no reply).

questions.sentence: When the phone rang, I ___ a shower.
questions.explanation: Past continuous describes an action in progress when another action (phone rang) happened.

questions.sentence: We ___ our friends for dinner tomorrow night.
questions.explanation: Present continuous can express fixed future arrangements, especially with specific time (tomorrow night).

questions.sentence: How long ___ you ___ for the bus?
questions.explanation: Present perfect continuous (have/has been + -ing) emphasizes duration of an action from past to now.

questions.sentence: By the time we arrived at the cinema, the movie ___ already ___.
questions.explanation: Past perfect shows an action completed before another past action (arrived).

questions.sentence: If it ___ tomorrow, we'll stay home.
questions.explanation: In first conditional sentences (if-clause), we use present simple for the condition, not 'will'.

questions.sentence: This is the first time I ___ sushi.
questions.explanation: After expressions like 'the first/second time', we use present perfect to show experience.

questions.sentence: When I was young, I ___ to ride a bicycle without training wheels.
questions.explanation: Past simple is used for completed actions in a finished time period (when I was young).

questions.sentence: Watch out! You ___ fall off that ladder!
questions.explanation: We use 'going to' for immediate predictions based on present evidence (danger is visible).

questions.sentence: My sister ___ harder these days to prepare for her exams.
questions.explanation: Present continuous describes temporary situations happening around now (these days).

questions.sentence: I can't find my wallet. I think I ___ it somewhere.
questions.explanation: Present perfect connects a past action (losing wallet) to a present consequence (can't find it).

questions.sentence: They ___ about their holiday when I joined the conversation.
questions.explanation: Past continuous shows an ongoing action when another action (joined) occurred.

questions.sentence: I promise I ___ late again.
questions.explanation: We use 'will' (or won't) to make promises about future behavior.

questions.sentence: She ___ all morning, so she's exhausted now.
questions.explanation: Present perfect continuous emphasizes the duration of a recent activity that affects the present (exhausted).

questions.sentence: I realized I ___ my phone at the restaurant.
questions.explanation: Past perfect shows the earlier action (leaving phone) before the later realization.

questions.sentence: The train ___ at 6:30 AM every morning.
questions.explanation: Present simple is used for scheduled events like timetables, especially with transport.

questions.sentence: My brother ___ to five different countries so far this year.
questions.explanation: Present perfect with 'so far' describes actions in an unfinished time period (this year).

questions.sentence: The company ___ its employees a bonus last December.
questions.explanation: Past simple is used for completed actions at a specific finished time (last December).

questions.sentence: I can't come tonight because I ___ my cousin at the airport.
questions.explanation: Present continuous expresses fixed future arrangements already planned.

questions.sentence: You ___ always ___ your homework at the last minute!
questions.explanation: Present continuous with 'always' expresses annoyance about a repeated habit.

questions.sentence: She didn't recognize me because we ___ each other for ten years.
questions.explanation: Past perfect shows the earlier state (not seeing) that caused the later result (didn't recognize).

questions.sentence: You look tired. How long ___ you ___?
questions.explanation: Present perfect continuous asks about the duration of an activity that explains a present situation (looking tired).

questions.sentence: While the teacher ___ the lesson, a student's phone ___.
questions.explanation: Past continuous for the background action (explaining), past simple for the interruption (rang).

questions.sentence: By this time next month, I ___ my degree.
questions.explanation: Future perfect (will have + past participle) describes an action that will be completed before a future time.

questions.sentence: I ___ three books this month, but last month I only ___ one.
questions.explanation: Use present perfect for unfinished time (this month) and past simple for finished time (last month).

questions.sentence: They were exhausted because they ___ for hours without a break.
questions.explanation: Past perfect continuous emphasizes the duration of an action before a past moment (being exhausted).

questions.sentence: If I ___ the job offer last year, I ___ in London now.
questions.explanation: Mixed conditional: past perfect in if-clause (past action) and would + be -ing in result (present consequence).

questions.tense: Present Perfect Continuous vs Present Perfect
questions.sentence: I ___ to contact him all day, but his phone is switched off.
questions.explanation: Present perfect continuous emphasizes repeated efforts throughout a period (all day).

questions.sentence: The house was very quiet when I got home. Everybody ___ to bed.
questions.explanation: Past perfect shows the earlier action (going to bed) before the later observation (house was quiet).

questions.sentence: This time tomorrow, I ___ on a beach in Hawaii.
questions.explanation: Future continuous (will be + -ing) describes an action that will be in progress at a specific future time.
